Early Access Review

Hmm...The concept is good, but there are some things I don't like. First and foremost, there are way too many microtransactions (AKA in-app purchases). To build something, you need to buy every single block with coins. To gather enough of them, you have two options; either keep playing and get them (which takes forever) or buy them with real money. So, by that aspect, you may feel kinda scammed, like I did.

Regarding the gameplay, it is really difficult to build. You'll have a hard time trying to place a block over another. Try it for your own, you'll see. Sometimes, the block hiding system doesn't work, thus making it impossible to play inside a room.

But wait, there are positives; as I mentioned beforehand, I liked the concept, even though it's not new. There is also a fully functional anti-grief system, which I admire, as there is no such thing in Minecraft or Terraria (yet).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The concept of 8BitMMO is great. A 100% player built world with combat and an infinite world? Sounds great, right?

The way it's executed, however, isn't as great.

Before I say anything else, I do /NOT/ believe that you need good graphics to make a good game. That being said, this games graphics are one of the major issues with this game. The majority of the tutorial is telling you what you're even looking at, for example how to distinguish an overpass from the floor below. I think this game would be MUCH better if it had depth. the way it is constructed makes it difficult to tell where you are in comparison to anything. When you go under something, it dissapears, but that leads to even more confusion when trying to navigate through someones building. Furthurmore, when attenpting to build, you must puild from north to south unless using slabs. Attempting to do otherwise causes you to place the block on top of the previously placed one. Trying to build roofs or multi-story buildings is a pain, and the game doesn't tell you how to place blocks in the air without building up untill after you've placed 30 blocks. This wouldn't be an issue, except for the fact that you need gold to buy blocks. In order to get gold, you need to kill enemies, which is a good concept, but as with the rest of the game, is poorly done. The combat in this game consists of either jabbing a super-close ranged sword at the enemy, or using a pixel pistol to shoot the foes down. Aiming properly is difficult, and even if you use the swords, combat is extremely bland and difficult.

There are so many things wrong with this game, the few things it does right are not enough to counter them. Like I said before, the concept is great, but I do not recommend this game.

Ugh, I know a bunch of people are going to dislike this, but I got bored. That's why i only played 2.5 hours. Ok, now the reasons.

8BitMMO is a fully player built world, that's a bad idea because there will be a bunch of players leaving blocks everywhere that serve no purpose. Plus I spent in-game coins on it, YES I had to spend my gold on those blocks. And it would be annoying to clean it all up. Also, the building system is bad. I have to go into my inventory, select the item, click the box to drop it, and that's it. Why can't I just select the block I currently have, and place it, like in games like Minecraft. Also, the game is shallow, there are only 3 npcs that give you quests. I would like more npc quests to be added, like in other mmos, so I don't have to run around doing horrible player quests, (more on that later). Also, i'm at level 3, I keep completing quests, and i'm not level 4 yet.  I'm still in the first 5 levels, what the heck i should be leveling up faster. reviewText:
This game kind of gets boring after a while. It at first was really fun, I enjoyed getting better gear, messing around with my pocket universe, and exploring the map. It slowly gets... kind of dull after a while though.

Combat
The enemies in this game are all the exact same, except they look different and have different stats. They will try to run at you, and hit you after 5 seconds. Needless to say, they are very easy to kill. PVP is pretty engaging at first, but gets old really quickly. You have 4 types of weapons that each work differently, and considering there is only one developer, this isn't that bad. The issue is the weapons themselves. There are three swords, exactly the same except in damage. There is a gun, that shoots little friendliness pellets at people, and it controls alright. The laser is pretty weird, you charge it for a few seconds, and it shoots a straight line. People actually have made good use of this in pvp, but it seems extermely easy to dodge. Lastly is the hammer, doing a massive area damage, but taking a while to charge. Each of these weapons can be specialized to do well in pvp, and people have become really good at pvp in this game. Regardless, it does get dull quickly, however it is worth trying out.
Community
The community is actually pretty helpful, when I played this game, I actually learned a lot from other people. The only issue is that for an MMO, there is pretty much nobody. 5-10 people are usually online at a time, which is pretty small considering a huge part of the game is Towns. It would be a much, much better game if it were more active. Because of recent events I have heard of (and not participated in, and as such will not talk about), and the game not really being updated, I doubt this will happen easily. The community that is there is fine, though.
Building
Ironically, this is probably the worst aspect of the game. Well, second worst. The mechanics are not that bad, it just takes getting used to. The issue is often, unless you are an expert and know what your doing, it won't turn look very good. This wouldn't be that bad if more materials were available, but microtransactions make it worse.
Microtransactions
I get it, I honestly get it. There has to be a way for servers to keep running, so microtransactions are used. Honestly though, when I get a game, I want all the features available (minus DLC, that's different). It's a bit like PVE, and PVE2. Plants vs Zombies costs some money, but it gives all the features immediately. Plants vs Zombies 2, on the other hand, is free. However, there are many micotransactions. I would rather just pay the $5. Not only do items cost money, though this is forgivable considering items aren't necessarilly needed, and they are obtainable through mystery boxes, but towns and pocket universes need money. Towns need money to make, and money to expand. Pocket Universes need money to expand. Even dungeons, a large gimmick of this game, need money to make. The good news is it's easy to get some items via players, and there are shops that sell them. The bad news is they are really expensive.
Style
The style of this game is actually not that bad. It doesn't look really good, but it's alright. The music is really on your taste, however. I personally don't mind it, but I can easily see people turn off the game after 5 minutes from it. It's essentially 8-bit dubstep. Ironically, it is one of the only aspects of the game that doesn't get old after a while.
Final Verdict
8-bit mmo, dispite it's flaws, is a fun game. It is a nice little game to pop in every now and then, mess around with, and leave. It isn't by any means horrible, but it isn't a masterpiece either. It's pretty fun for the first 10-20 hours, but then gets dull, depending on your taste. That being said, you should try it out, and if it isn't your style, forget about it. Because of the numerous flaws, and it being boring after a short while, I'm going to have to give it a 5/10. See if you like it, but if it doesn't look like your cup of tea, skip it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, after tinkering around with this game for a short while, I've got an idea of this game. The graphics are pretty shoddy and look kinda off when you move, but they work (for the most part, anyway, determining what layer a block is on is tricky and overhangs just vanish when you're under them). The music is honestly quite enjoyable, but nothing fantastic.

Gameplay is simple, but effective: both combat and building have little to them but still satisfied me nonetheless. The menus do their job, but aren't special and don't really look pretty. The NPCs have nice designs (and the ones that speak are often humorous) but enemy AI is incredibly simple and similar.

I can't really comment on the MMO aspect, as I prefer playing solo. But for an MMO, I enjoyed my time alone, which is generally a good sign. I've heard complaints of being only playable if you shovel money into it, but I honestly didn't feel that way at all. Overall, the game is lacking. However, there are three factors that stop me from not reccomending this:

1) The game is in early access. The biggest problems I have with this game (namely, the artwork and the simplicity) can be very easily fixed with future updates.

2) There's just a certain...CHARM the game has. With it's designs and it's dialogue and it's style...there's just something about this game that I love, even if it isn't that great on closer examination.

3) The game is free. There is really nothing stopping you from at least trying it out and making a decision.

TL;DR: The game is simple and somewhat lazy, but charming and free.

reviewText:
Thirteen hours in the last few days, and I still can't quite figure out why I like this game. The graphics are, indeed 8-bit, though the colors are more like 16 bit. 32 bit if you play with the flesh tone color change option (/color <0-9>), as some of the variances are too subtle for 16 bit.

You can mod your textures very easily. Which, I did do... Since I was sick of blue glass that you couldn't see through and neon green grass that makes your eyes water. All it takes to mod is a zip file creator and a paint program with transparency.... Go check the community, there's a FAQ for that.

Some of the stuff you really want is limited to platinum, which is only available through real-world money. Though, there are people that buy plat items and sell them for gold. (Regular quest cash.) These can go in the houses you build or - honestly - just about anywhere in the world. You can even found towns and build them up with friends.

Maybe that's what I like about this game.... When I used to play all those 8 and 16 bit RPGs, I used to think to myself that I could make better houses. This is my chance. (And, yes, I am a fanatic for a certain game that starts with an 's' and ends with 'ims.')

Also, the game isn't that difficult. I find that making money is a breeze once you buy a gun and just sit just barely in range of a spawner. Levelling to 4 was long, but - if you do the draco and brain quests - not terribly bad. The draco quests can be repeated by clearing your quest log, by the way. I haven't hit 5 yet, but I'm on the way and looking forward to opening up some more blocks to build with. I'm also really looking forward to gathering enough gold to buy a spawner off of someone that has plat, so I can make a shooting range.

reviewText:
When I play a videogame (regardless of genre), I expect it to grab me by the arms and drag me into it's world. I want to be fully engrossed in it's universe, story, and gameplay.

Personally, 8BitMMO did none of this for me.

Now, I realize I didn't play this game for very long. I plan to play more of it in the coming days, to really give it a fair shot. I also realize that the focus of this game leans more towards user created content then a narrative-heavy experience. I GET that. But what 8BitMMo is supposed to do, it doesn't seem to do particularly well. It just hasn't made a great impression so far.

PROS:
--Somewhat clever sense of humor
--Relatively empty servers
--Easy to pick up and play
--Does not require an email address to play

Cons:
--World-building, an already slow and unintersting affair (and unfortunately the whole point of the game), is made more difficult via microtransactions.
--Gameplay is fundamentally oversimplified, and not very interesting as a result.
--Quests lack challenge and variety
--Performance issues-notably server lag.

It's just hard to reccomend an MMO like this when there are so many better experiences available.

reviewText: Honestly, this game was a disappointment. At first, this game looked amazing, fun, and well put together. But that's just in the trailor. The truth is,  when you actually begin to play the game, you notice a lot that went wrong. First, it's incredibly hard to figure out how to play. The tutorial doesn't tell you much at all about what you're supposed to do, or how to get started. Second, the block layouts are all very 'chunky' and hard to work with. You can barely tell where blocks actually are, what level they're at, or where a wall is.\nThis game has a camera view very similar to old 8 bit games, but the view genuinely sucks. You can't even see the sides of blocks so even with the different layers, this game doesn't even have a 3d feel to it. Other than that, the character art is awful, battles don't make much sense, and I couldn't even figure out just by playing the game if there's an inventory system.\nIn general, I would rate 8bitMMO 3/10. I just couldn't see a good side to the game.

I came in, expecting a cheap but fun retro-style MMO where you build stuff. Instead I got a cheap and unfun game with poor hit detection, lots of lag and a rather aggressive player base. The gameplay, while simplistic, doesn't always function the way you want it to, concepts of the game aren't explained well in it's tutorials, and there is no way that I could find of telling when I was getting hit, so I ended up dying when it appeared I was doing really well. The graphics are more akin to a late-era Atari 2600 game as opposed to an 8-bit console, which sort of ruins the entire 8-bit feel. I guess some of the music is catchy, though some of it is also not so good, so it's rather hit-and-miss.

I did not spend that much time with the game, but the time I did spend was enough to convince me that this game is not for me, and most likely not a game that was well made. I'd say avoid this one, it's just not worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA retro-themed construction mmo. Build alone or with friends. After taking a little time to learn the z-axis mechanics, the system is quite easy to understand and flexible. Don't go in expecting it to be combat-driven, or too complex in the PvP department. Building is the primary focus here, and in this regard it excels. The community will usually answer any questions you may have promptly if you get stuck, just make sure you're polite, and the kindness will be reciprocated. A single developer runs this entire game, so updates are slow, however imput from the players is always taken into consideration. If minecraft-esque construction with a retro twist sounds appealing to you, give 8BitMMO a try.

There are also items called mystery boxes, so you can buy plat items only with gold. There is so much you can do on this game! it depends entirely on what you want to do. If you like making pixel art, there are many blocks that provide colors to do so. One player (Sage) made realistic looking people using only blocks he/she could buy in-game. If you like being a popular and admired player, you can give or sell plat items. In total 8bitMMO is one of the best games i have ever encountered.

It is a  fun causual game. but if you are looking for a hard core MMO to play with friends then this is not the game. I found it fun for the first few hours, but i cannot see this being a game where I bulid a Giant castle. The game right know has a small community so I would personall suggest waiting Exactly a month after the release day. So my first Complaint is that it gets hard to see from time to time when going through the sides. Another small gripe for me is the fact all the Characters look the same, I think that it needs a Character custumization complete with races, hair color, faces, and eye color, it would be something to make the game seem less monotonus. There is almost no Custimization in this game, Aside from Building, also for building you will need to be social in this game other wise you will be having a hard time finding a place to build outside in the world. There is almost no combat in this game though, and the combat that is in it is very monotuns.

But there are posotives, The user created content is good because it allows creativity annd the building of the masses. Some good thing is are the personal plots of land that you can get which then allow you to have some land that can not be trifled with. I enjoy the silly art style and the fact it never takes itself to serously.

So Ultimatley i found this to be an enjoyable pixaleated mix of Minecraft and Terria, The community is fair. So I give this game a good 4 out of ten 10, which is pretty good for an indi Developed game like this, i suggest a buy when it drops below five dollars, it will give you atleast an hour of enjoyment.

After spending only 20 minutes trying to deal with the slow tutorial, lousy controls, I have an 8bit headache.

I hopped into the game with really nothing on my mind and nothing to expect. This was an 8bit MMO that features building stuff and I honestly didn't know what to think.

After playing the slow and annoying tutorial and dealing with the no so good controls, I decided to talk to the people in chat and got invited to visit some guys mansion/castle/whatever that 8bit thing was and I was kinda surprised that someone could finish something that big on that game. My brain hurt after 20 minutes, this guy must of spent atleast several hours completing his 8bit fortress of headaches.

The dialogue is also bland and features no depth to what your doing, it felt like I was jumping into a poorly built 90's game.

I recommend not touching this and just skip over to another free MMO on steam, like Neverwinter or CoS.

Unless you have the patience of a saint and really love confusing gameplay, then take a stab at it.

Awful controls, really annoying tutorial and a general feeling of overwhelming boredom shot this down long before it took flight.

reviewText:
8BitMMO, created by Robby Zinchak aka RobbyZ is a old school styled Free Roam Rpg. 8BitMMO is a game that takes inspiration from many games such as Minecraft, Legend of Zelda, and even Mario. In 8BitMMO you start off waking up in a man's house who is completely aware that he is in a video game by breaking the 4th wall. He sends you off to complete quests in order to just get you out of his house, he references that he has done this multiple times and that strangers waking up in his house has become a common problem for him. This snarky dialogue made me enjoy my first 10 minutes of the game, as it reminded me of dialogue coming from games like Saints Row. I love it when games make fun of the fact that it is a game. Unfortunately after the tutorial this dialogue seemed to cease and enjoyment of my gameplay experience began to decrease more and more. The combat in 8BitMMO is simple enough to play with one hand, with occasionaly reaching for your mouse. Only having the WASD keys for movement and the space bar for attacking made hunting quests and fighting off enemies a bore after the tutorial. There is also another element that makes 8BitMMO a little more entertaining; the ability to build. You are able to build a houses and environments like a top down Minecraft or Terraria. The building can become tedious with blocks stacking not the way you want them to and having a lack of tools to do anything truly spectacular. Although I didnt enjoy this feature, I did see many interesting and cool user created homes and even areas that put the building and combat to good use. The music is probably what I enjoyed most from 8BitMMO, it had beats that went along with the art direction and it had the convenient feature to skip the current song as if i was using Pandora radio. The game does have a leveling system like most other MMO's that encourage you to rank up in order to get certain items or get to certain areas. I have to completely honest and say that I didnt have a great time with 8BitMMO. It is free on Steam and does offer microtransactions, BUT doesnt flash them around begging for money. The game might be fun with a few friends looking to make your own quests and adventures but playing alone is just plain boring.

Overall:

8BitMMO has a lot of great ideas that just dont work out yet. After sometime and update the game can be great. The music fits in with the world perfectly and the combat is a little bland. In my opinion I would like to see RobbyZ create either more content for this game or make more games with the same amount of snark and wit that the tutorial of this game had. I loved the original dialogue and was set to play a game that knew how to make fun of its self but instead, I got a bland and lifeless world that could and should be improved dramatically. And could be alot of fun if your bored with nothing new to play or if you find a group to play with.(Roleplaying could be fun in this game)

Whether you are a creative mind, or just a casual gamer, there is a place in 8BitMMO for you.
I highly reccommend downloading the game and trying it out.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n8BitMMO in my opinion seems to be a game where building a community is key. You don't get handed your materials and get sent out to mine and craft them though like several other games out there. Instead you have two systems working and playing off of each other. On one hand you have the RPG section. Here the system handles your characters progression, shop system, quests, economey and the most importing thing, FIGHTING THE BAD GUYS! On the other hand you have have the Building system that directly feeds off of the RPG system. You fight monsters which nets you gold and expierence which can net you more expierence and gold from a quest but most importantly it lets you get your materials to build. The shop is tiered in such a way that your level dictates what you can buy in the various sections of the shop and you use the gold you gain to purchase the items. You can then take the materials you purchase to your own Pocket Dimension. Here you can build what you want then invite people to visit or open it up to the public. The game has heart behind it. I can clearly see inspirations, aspirations and a future for this game, if it can quickly evolve and try to weather the storm.

reviewText:
Hmm...
The concept is good, but there are some things I don't like. First and foremost, there are way too many microtransactions (AKA in-app purchases). To build something, you need to buy every single block with coins. To gather enough of them, you have two options; either keep playing and get them (which takes forever) or buy them with real money. So, by that aspect, you may feel kinda scammed, like I did.

Regarding the gameplay, it is really difficult to build. You'll have a hard time trying to place a block over another. Try it for your own, you'll see. Sometimes, the block hiding system doesn't work, thus making it impossible to play inside a room.

But wait, there are positives; as I mentioned beforehand, I liked the concept, even though it's not new. There is also a fully functional anti-grief system, which I admire, as there is no such thing in Minecraft or Terraria (yet).

Summary:
I do like the fact that you can create your own adventure and play with friends and stuff like that, but the actual gameplay (in it's current stage) is a bit (heh, puns) lacking in certain places. Yes, I know it's an early-access title and that it's still in-development, but I would like to see a bit (heh, another pun) style and diversity in the combat and and customization of your character. Now, in regards to platinum, I don't like the fact that there is no conversion rate between the gold and platinum, and I do not agree that everything should cost platinum after level 3, but, because it's an early-access title this is probably just a temporary donation system and may be worked on as the game is updated more. As for the enemies and combat, I would like to see a bit more variation, maybe a randomly occuring dragon attack or space invasion you have to defend your town against, meanwhile, the combat shows a bit (I swear, I'm on fire today with these puns) of potential, I would like to see a magic/mana system worked into the combat. Other than that, I would say that because this game is free at the moment, you should download it and play it. It shows a lot of potential, and I would really like to see this turn into something great!
